repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
## Description

`nvim_buf_delete` now accepts an `action` string that can take the following

  - "wipeout": Equivalent to |:bufwipeout|
  - "unload":  Equivalent to |:bunload|
  - "delete":  Equivalent to |:bdelete|

**NOTE**: the old `unload` flag is handled internally to avoid creating breaking-change.

comment_data.body: It would be nice if we could store the action string and use that instead of "delete". `api_set_error` already supports format strings so it should be trivial to do so.
don't use "please" in docs or messages, it's unnecessary and just takes up space
nit: it's not really an action , i will try to suggest a different name
I was going off based on the name of the enum https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/081eb72a80afd83398465382171765bdeaf6dba5/src/nvim/buffer.h#L39-L46

It's definitely good to follow existing precedent, but for interfaces we often want to use precedent at the interface level (user-facing in this case) rather than internal C idioms.

But I can't think of a much better name. In `:help api` it looks like `type` is fairly common. So this could be named `type`.

I feel like `type` in this case is likely to imply the buffer type, rather than the operation type, as if it's a filtering parameter, e.g.

```lua
vim.api.nvim_bufdelete(buffer=0, {type="prompt"})
```

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

title: feat(api): add bdelete to nvim_buf_delete
